com.neovisionaries.datetime
Class GCalendar

java.lang.Object
  java.util.Calendar
      java.util.GregorianCalendar
          com.neovisionaries.datetime.GCalendar
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable<java.util.Calendar>
public class GCalendar
extends java.util.GregorianCalendar

A subclass of GregorianCalendar that provides some utility methods such as getYear().

GCalendar provides getXxx(), setXxx(), addXxx() and rollXxx() methods for each Calendar field. For example, getYear() method exists. In addition, some format() and parse() methods are available.

GregorianCalendar class has isLeapYear(int year) method, but it is not a static method. On the other hand, GCalendar provides no-argument isLeapYear() instance method and isLeap(int year) as a static method. Some constructor variants, for example, GCalendar(Date), are provided, too.

Author:
Takahiko Kawasaki
See Also:
Serialized Form

isLeapYear

public boolean isLeapYear()
Check if the year of this calendar object is a leap year.

Returns:
True if the year of this calendar object is a leap year.

isLeap

public static boolean isLeap(int year)
Check if the given year is a leap year. The implementation does the following. 

 return new GCalendar().setYear(year).isLeapYear();

Parameters:
year -
Returns:
True if the given year is a leap year.

format

public static java.lang.String format(java.text.DateFormat format,
                                      java.util.Calendar calendar)
Format the given calendar object using the given format. The implementation does the following. 

 return format.format(calendar.getTime());

format

public static java.lang.String format(java.lang.String format,
                                      java.util.Calendar calendar)
Format the given calendar object using the given format. The implementation does the following. 

 DateFormat df = new SimpleDateFormat(format);

 df.setTimeZone(calendar.getTimeZone());

 return format(df, calendar);

format

public java.lang.String format(java.text.DateFormat format)
Format this calendar object using the given format. The implementation does the following. 

 return format(format, this);

format

public java.lang.String format(java.lang.String format)
Format this calendar object using the given format. The implementation does the following. 

 return format(format, this);

format

public static java.lang.StringBuffer format(java.text.DateFormat format,
                                            java.util.Calendar calendar,
                                            java.lang.StringBuffer toAppendTo,
                                            java.text.FieldPosition position)
Format the given calendar object using the given format. The implementation does the following. 

 return format.format(calendar.getTime(), toAppendTo, position);

format

public static java.lang.StringBuffer format(java.lang.String format,
                                            java.util.Calendar calendar,
                                            java.lang.StringBuffer toAppendTo,
                                            java.text.FieldPosition position)
Format the given calendar object using the given format. The implementation does the following. 

 DateFormat df = new SimpleDateFormat(format);

 df.setTimeZone(calendar.getTimeZone());

 return format(df, calendar, toAppendTo, position);

 return parse(new SimpleDateFormat(format), source);

parse

public static GCalendar parse(java.text.DateFormat format,
                              java.lang.String source,
                              java.text.ParsePosition position)
Parse the given string using the given format. First, the implementation creates a Date object by calling format.parse(source, position). If the parse() method returns a non-null value, a new GCalendar object is created by new GCalendar(Date) and returned. Otherwise, null is returned.

parse

public static GCalendar parse(java.lang.String format,
                              java.lang.String source,
                              java.text.ParsePosition position)
Parse the given string using the given format. The implementation does the following. 

 return parse(new SimpleDateFormat(format), source, position);

Set 0 to hourOfDay field, minute, second and millisecond fields.

Returns:
this object.

setNoon

public GCalendar setNoon()
Set 12 to hourOfDay field, and set 0 to minute, second and millisecond fields.

Returns:
this object.

changeTimeZoneOnly

public GCalendar changeTimeZoneOnly(java.util.TimeZone timeZone)
Change the time zone, but preserve the values of year, month dayOfMonth, hourOfDay, minute, second and millisecond.

The code snippet below: 


 import java.util.TimeZone;
 import com.neovisionaries.datetime.GCalendar;

 public class GCalTest
 {
     public static void main(String[] args)
     {
         TimeZone GMT = TimeZone.getTimeZone("GMT");
         TimeZone JST = TimeZone.getTimeZone("JST");
         GCalendar cal;

         // Create an instance with a different time zone than GMT.
         cal = new GCalendar(JST);
         print(cal);

         // Change the time zone to GMT, but preserve other fields.
         //
         // Year, month, ..., millisecond won't change, but
         // timeInMillis will change.
         cal.changeTimeZoneOnly(GMT);
         print(cal);

         // Create an instance with a different time zone than GMT.
         cal = new GCalendar(JST);
         print(cal);

         // Change the time zone to GMT.
         //
         // timeInMillis won't change, but the hourOfDay field
         // (and possibly others) will change.
         cal.setTimeZone(GMT);
         print(cal);
     }


     private static void print(GCalendar cal)
     {
         System.out.format("%04d/%02d/%02d %02d:%02d:%02d " +
                           "(offset = %8d, timeInMillis = %d)\n",
             cal.getYear(), cal.getMonth() + 1, cal.getDayOfMonth(),
             cal.getHourOfDay(), cal.getMinute(), cal.getSecond(),
             cal.getZoneOffset(), cal.getTimeInMillis());
     }
 }

will generate output like the following. 

 2012/11/15 17:45:47 (offset = 32400000, timeInMillis = 1352969147188)
 2012/11/15 17:45:47 (offset =        0, timeInMillis = 1353001547188)
 2012/11/15 17:45:47 (offset = 32400000, timeInMillis = 1352969147206)
 2012/11/15 08:45:47 (offset =        0, timeInMillis = 1352969147206)

Parameters:
timeZone -
Returns:
this object.

changeTimeZoneOnly

public GCalendar changeTimeZoneOnly(java.lang.String timeZone)
Change the time zone, but preserve the values of year, month dayOfMonth, hourOfDay, minute, second and millisecond.

This method is an alias of changeTimeZoneOnly(TimeZone.getTimeZone(timeZone)).

Parameters:
timeZone - String expression of a time zone.
Returns:
this object.
Since:
1.1

toISO8601

public java.lang.String toISO8601()
Format this calendar object using ISO 8601 extended format (yyyy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ssZ, where Z is [+-]HH:mm). This format complies with XMLSchema dateTime format, too. 

 TimeZone tz = TimeZone.getTimeZone("JST");
 GCalendar cal = new GCalendar(tz, 1974, Calendar.MAY, 6, 12, 34, 56, 0);

 // This prints "1974-05-06T12:34:56+09:00".
 System.out.println( cal.toISO8601() );

Since:
1.2
See Also:
ISO 8601, XMLSchema dateTime format
